Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Remove Usabilla" (#8417) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Merge branch 'master' into dev" (#8416) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "nuget restore results in a package integrity check failure on big endian system" (#10567) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe 

Product version: Built from master

Worked before: N/A

## Repro steps and/or sample project

A run of `dotnet build` on a big endian system borks with `The package integrity check failed.` when `msbuild` tries to restore packages

The `VerifySignedPackageIntegrity` method is not endian-aware which results in a verification failure. The attached patch works for both little and big endian systems and may provide insight into creating a _real_ solution to the problem.

[diff-nuget.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5969176/diff-nuget.txt)

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Codespaces - PM UI didn't refresh package list upon changing package source" (#10537) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe): Visual Studio 16.10 P1

Product version: 5.10.0.7102

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: I am unable to reproduce this issue in standalone/classic VS

## Repro steps and/or sample project

<!-- Please add as much details as possible to help us to reproduce your problem. -->

- Sever and Client instance of Codespace are running locally.
- Cloned this repo https://github.com/nkolev92/NuGet.VS.Oe.TestBed locally
- Connected to above repo using Codespaces
- Navigated to `Manage NuGet Packages` window for `Library2` project
- Removed `nuget.org` from package source

**Actual**
- Packages list didn't refresh

**Expected**
- Packages list to refresh like classic/standalone VS

![pmui-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52756182/106949983-9a29ba00-66e2-11eb-80a4-c68ddcf60c41.gif)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Preventing the "Dependency Confusion" attack" (#10566) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

A security researcher has [publicized a "Dependency Confusion" problem](https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610)<sup>1</sup> that affects most package managers, and I suspect nuget is affected as well.

For example, say my company has an internal nuget package, named `mycompany-logger`, hosted on an internal nuget server. If someone uploads a malicious package with the same name to nuget.org, with either an equal or slightly higher version, would a package restore pull down this malicious package instead?

## Research Done

Initially, I thought that using a NuGet.config with the company internal packageSource listed first would stop this, but I see [the following documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuget-config-file#packagesources):

> The order is ignored during restore operations and with any project using the PackageReference format.

One way of solving this might be adding the ability to pin a nuget package to a particular packageSource, so e.g. `mycompany-logger` would only ever be downloaded from the internal nuget server. Are there any ways to mitigate this today? Thanks.


<sub><sup>1</sup> This is a Medium article, if the link is blocked see [this alternate source](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/researcher-hacks-over-35-tech-firms-in-novel-supply-chain-attack/ ).</sub>

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unit Test is system Timezone dependent: `Commands.Test.NugetPackageUtilsTests.Test_ExtractionHonorsFileTimestamp`" (#10565) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem
A test failed for me, and a quick look seems to indicate the Actual timestamp is pertinent to my timezone.
Tests should be passing regardless of the system's timezone.

`Commands.Test.NugetPackageUtilsTests.Test_ExtractionHonorsFileTimestamp`

Expected: 1985-11-20T12:00:00.0000000
Actual:   1985-11-20**T07:00:00.0000000-05:00**

## Repro steps and/or sample project

<!-- Please add as much details as possible to help us to reproduce your problem. -->

<!-- Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...) -->
[CoreUnitTests-xunit.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5962635/CoreUnitTests-xunit.zip)

```
<test name="Commands.Test.NugetPackageUtilsTests.Test_ExtractionHonorsFileTimestamp" type="Commands.Test.NugetPackageUtilsTests" method="Test_ExtractionHonorsFileTimestamp" time="0.2278019" result="Fail">
        <failure exception-type="Xunit.Sdk.EqualException">
          <message><![CDATA[Assert.Equal() Failure\r\nExpected: 1985-11-20T12:00:00.0000000\r\nActual:   1985-11-20T07:00:00.0000000-05:00]]></message>
          <stack-trace><![CDATA[   at Commands.Test.NugetPackageUtilsTests.<Test_ExtractionHonorsFileTimestamp>d__11.MoveNext() in C:\NuGet.Client\test\NuGet.Core.Tests\NuGet.Packaging.Test\NugetPackageUtilTests.cs:line 664
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)]]></stack-trace>
        </failure>
      </test>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore failing on .NET 5 for Debian-based OSes" (#49) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey Everyone,

Our preliminary investigation shows that .NET 5 restore is broken for Debian-based operating systems including Docker thus resulting in error messages like:

```
error NU3037: Package 'System.Memory 4.5.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The author primary signature validity period has expired.
```

### [Debian Versions](https://www.debian.org/releases/)
- We're currently aware that Debian 10 ("buster") and earlier versions are affected. ❌
- We do know that Debian testing ("bullseye") and later are not affected. ✔

This is because of an [issue reported](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962596) in the `ca-certificates` package in which the root CA being used are not trusted and must be installed manually due to [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues). Because this issue has been resolved recently in version 20210119 of this package, it is not available in a Debian version as provided in `dotnet-docker` for `buster-slim` today.

## Workarounds

- Manually update the [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/ca-certificates) package to version 20210119 including a `bullseye` or later version.
- Consider using a different Debian-based Docker image such as `alpine` or `focal`.
 
## Solution

We're currently working to update the `dotnet-docker`'s `buster-slim` image to update the `ca-certificates` package to 20210119 that resolves this issue. We are however currently verifying this is a viable solution with no large diffs between the `buster` and `bullseye` releases.

Additionally, the `ca-certificates` package is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive which will promote this fix to the `buster` release in the next few days to which an updated `buster-slim` image will be prepared and released when available.

## Stay Updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We'll continue to update the discussion at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10491.
- We will also continue posting updates on https://status.nuget.org and on Twitter @NuGet.
